title-group.article-title: Two new species of erect Bryozoa (Gymnolaemata: Cheilostomata) and the application of non-destructive imaging methods for quantitative taxonomy

sec.p: Two new species of erect Bryozoa (Gymnolaemata: Cheilostomata ) and
the application of non-destructive imaging methods for quantitative taxonomy

KEI MATSUYAMA 1 , JÜRGEN TITSCHACK1,2, DANIEL BAUM 3 & ANDRÉ FREIWALD 11 Senckenberg am Meer, Abteilung Meeresforschung, Südstrand 40, 26382 Wilhelmshaven, Germany . E-mail: kei.matsuyama@senckenberg.de
2 MARUM—Center of Marine Environmental Sciences, University of Bremen, Leobener Straße, 28359 Bremen, Germany3 ZIB—Zuse Institute Berlin, Takustraße 7, 14195 Berlin-Dahlem, Germany

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Two new species of cheilostome Bryozoa are described from continental-slope habitats off Mauritania , including canyon and cold-water coral (mound) habitats. Internal structures of both species were visualised and quantified using microcomputed tomographic (micro-CT) methods. Cellaria bafouri n. sp. is characterised by the arrangement of zooids in alternating longitudinal rows, a smooth cryptocyst, and the presence of an ooecial plate with denticles. Smittina imragueni n. sp. exhibits many similarities with Smittina cervicornis (
Pallas, 1766 )
, but differs especially in the shape and orientation of the suboral avicularium. Observations on Smittina imragueni and material labelled as Smittina cervicornis suggest that the latter represents a species group, members of which have not yet been discriminated, possibly because of high intracolony variation and marked astogenetic changes in surface morphology. Both new species are known only from the habitats where they were collected, probably reflecting the paucity of bryozoan sampling from this geographic area and depth range. Both species are able to tolerate low oxygen concentration, which is assumed to be compensated by the high nutrient supply off Mauritania . The application of micro-CT for the semiautomatic quantification of zooidal skeletal characters was successfully tested. We were able to automatically distinguish individual zooidal cavities and acquire corresponding morphological datasets. Comparing the obtained results with conventional SEM measurements allowed ascertaining the reliability of this new method. The employment of micro-CT allows the observation and quantification of previously unseen characters that can be used in describing and differentiating species that were previously indistinguishable. Furthermore, this method might help elucidate processes of colony growth and the function of individual zooids during this process.
Key words:Mauritania , Northeast Atlantic, continental margin, micro-CT, Cellaria , Smittina

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Records of Bryozoa from waters off Mauritania are scarce. The first comprehensive studies that also included this area were published by Canu & Bassler (1925 , 1928 ), describing bryozoans collected mainly on the Vanneau cruise, together with some minor collections by several researchers and amateur naturalists. Later, d’Hondt ( 1978 ) concluded this short series by describing some remaining Bryozoa collected by the Vanneau . The majority of species described in these publications, however, are from Moroccan waters. Cook (1968 , 1985 ) intensively studied the West African bryozoan fauna, but only occasionally mentioned bryozoans off Mauritania . Records of Bryozoa growing on cold-water corals appear only sporadically in all these publications. This is also the case on a global scale, as bryozoans appear either in faunal lists of the cold-water coral-associated fauna (e.g.
Le Danois 1948 ;
Rogers 1999 ;
Rosso et al . 2010 ), or cold-water corals appear coincidentally as substrata for bryozoans in general taxonomic works (e.g.
Ryland 1963 ; Harmelin & d’Hondt 1992 a,b). Notable exceptions are
Zabala et al . ( 1993 )
and
López-Fé ( 2006 )
, who focused entirely on cold-water coral-associated bryozoans.

The continental margin off Mauritania is marked by the presence of the most southern deep-water coral mounds known in the eastern North Atlantic, comprising Lophelia pertusa (
Linnaeus, 1758 )
and Madrepora oculata (
Linnaeus, 1758 )
. These represent one of the largest coral-mound provinces, with a latitudinal extent exceeding 200 km (
Colman et al . 2005 ;
Westphal et al . 2007 ). The mound province extends from north of the Cap Timiris Canyon System (
Krastel et al . 2004 ) to the Mauritanian Slide Complex in the south (
Wien et al . 2007 ). Coral mounds occur at depths between 450 and 550 m , in the lower and less-depleted part of a pronounced oxygenminimum zone, caused by one of the largest upwelling systems worldwide (
Hagen 2001 ), making the waters off Mauritania highly productive (
Gabric et al . 1993 ;
Marañón & Holligan 1999 ). The living corals form small, isolated colonies, only infrequently forming larger aggregations, and most often colonising canyon walls or isolated rock outcrops. Bryozoans seem to appear in great diversity and abundance in these coral habitats (
Westphal et al . 2012 ).

The present study contributes to a first comprehensive assessment of the upper-bathyal bryozoan fauna from cold-water coral habitats and closely adjacent areas off Mauritania by describing two new cheilostome species from these environments. We also discuss the required environmental conditions and habitat preferences of both species. The identifications and descriptions are based on conventional micrographs from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) that were further substantiated by microcomputed tomography (micro-CT). So far, micro-CT has been used primarily to visualise internal structures of Recent and fossil cheilostomes (
Schmidt 2012 ; Koromyslova & Pakhnevich 2014 ), Recent and fossil cyclostomes (Taylor et al . 2008 ; Koromyslova et al . 2014 ), fossil boring ctenostomes (
Viskova & Pakhnevich 2010 ), fossil fenestrates (
Wyse Jackson & McKinney 2013 ) and fossil trepostomes (
Buttler et al . 2012 ), although
Klicpera et al . ( 2013 )
used micro-CT analysis to measure and estimate the ratio of calcitic skeleton to the total volume of a single zooid. The results of our study highlight the capabilities and possibilities offered by micro-CT to visualise and quantify internal skeletal structures. We also tested the reliability of semiautomatic quantification of zooecial characters by comparing them with conventional SEM analyses.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Bryozoan specimens were retrieved from surface-sediment samples collected during RV Maria S. Merian cruise MSM 16 / 3 “PHAETON – Paleoceanographic and paleoclimatic record on the Mauritanian shelf” ( 13 October – 20 November 2010 ) off Mauritania (
Westphal et al . 2012 ). Sampling was performed by using a box corer with an opening of 50 × 50 cm and a height of 55 cm , a grab sampler, and a remotely operated vehicle (ROV) (Sperre SubFighter 7500 DC of The Tjärnö Centre for Underwater Documentation, Sven Lovén Centre for Marine Sciences Tjärnö, University of Gothenburg, Strömstad, Sweden ). A total of 25 coral-rubble samples, partly with living coral specimens still present, were screened for bryozoans using a Zeiss Stemi 2000 stereomicroscope, revealing about 60 species. The two new cheilostome species, present in 13 out of the 25 coral rubble samples, were selected for the micro-CT analysis. These 13 samples were representative of the highly variable seafloor topography in the area investigated, comprising coral mounds, canyons and positions in between, which allowed an assessment of habitat preferences (
,
Table 1 ).

For further examination, taxonomic identification and description, specimens were treated with household bleach comprising 2.8 g /l sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours to remove non-skeletal material, which might increase the complexity of the reconstruction and volumetric rendering of the skeleton. The specimen of Cellaria bafouri n. sp. chosen for micro-CT analysis was additionally cleaned in an ultrasonic bath to remove small sand grains clogging some of the opesiae.

Images of uncoated material were taken using a Tescan VEGA3 XMU SEM using a BSE-detector in lowvacuum mode ( 20 Pa) at Senckenberg am Meer, Wilhelmshaven, Germany . Conventional measurements, i.e. dimensions of orifices and zooecia, were made on SEM micrographs using ImageJ ver. 1.49 software.

One selected specimen of each species ( SMF40003 and SMF40010 ) was scanned with a Skyscan (now Bruker MicroCT) micro-CT for SEM attached to the SEM mentioned above. This instrument uses an X-ray source formed by focusing an electron beam onto a copper target. The X-rays pass through the rotating sample and are detected by a high-resolution X-ray camera. The scanning parameters for both specimens were: source voltage 30 kV, source current 2 mA, rotation step 0.45 ° and 360 ° rotation. These conditions resulted in a resolution of approximately 4 µm. The rotational dataset obtained was reconstructed using NRecon ver. 1.6 . 3.3 (Skyscan) software into 504 horizontally orientated slices, each slice forming a 512 × 512 pixel image.

The data were processed with the ZIB (Zuse Institute Berlin) edition of Amira software (version 2014.51 ) (
Stalling et al . 2005 ; http://amira.zib.de). Zooid cavities were segmented by the ambient occlusion algorithm (Baum & Titschack in prep.), which allowed separation of bryozoan pore space from the surrounding sample space (both consisting of air). Single-zooid and avicularian chamber segmentation, as well as the segmentation of opesiae and rhizoidal pores, were subsequently performed with the SegmentationEditor module. Size determinations were obtained with the ShapeAnalysis module. For each segmental entity, we present the maximum extent in the three primary directions, as well as the volume. These values correspond to the proximal-distal length, ventral-dorsal depth and lateral width of an autozooidal chamber, in decreasing order. For the avicularian chamber of Smittina imragueni n. sp. and the opesiae of Cellaria bafouri n. sp. , the largest value is the lateral width. Finally, the segmentation results were exported as Surfaces and the ShapeAnalysis results were exported as spreadsheets and further processed in Microsoft Excel.

Measurements obtained from SEM images and micro-CT datasets were statistically evaluated using PAST3.06 (
Hammer et al . 2001 ). Normal distribution was tested using the Shapiro-Wilk test. Welchs’s t-test, which returns robust results even if the variances of the samples are unequal, was used to test the equality of means. Significance level was set at 0.05 .

The classification herein follows the working scheme of Cheilostomata by D.P. Gordon (pers. comm. 2014 ) for eventual publication in the revised Treatise on Invertebrate Paleontology . The specimens of the new species described herein are lodged in the bryozoan collections of the Forschungsinstitut und Naturmuseen Senckenberg, Sektion Marine Evertebraten III, Frankfurt am Main, Germany , registered under SMF40001 to SMF40011 . Some comparative material was examined at the Natural History Museum, Department of Life Sciences, London, UK ( NHMUK ).

tp:treatment-sec.p: Type species. Farcimia sinuosa Hassall, 1840

Material examined.Holotype : SMF40001 , station GeoB 14904 -1, 17° 32.559 ʹ N, 16 ° 39.805 ʹ W, 510 m , Tamxat Mound Complex. Paratypes : SMF40002 , station GeoB 14911 -1, 17° 28.910 ʹ N, 16 ° 41.509 ʹ W, 450 m , Tamxat Mound Complex; SMF40003 , station GeoB 14760 -2, 19° 44.292 ʹ N, 17 °08.754ʹ W, 478 m , Arguin Canyon; SMF40004 , station GeoB 14802 -1, 20° 14.791 ʹ N, 17 ° 40.188 ʹ W, 595 m , Tanoudert Canyon.
Etymology. The species name is derived from the Bafour, pre-Islamic inhabitants of what is now Mauritania .
Diagnosis.Cellaria with subhexagonal zooids in alternating longitudinal rows, a smooth cryptocyst, two stout, frontally directed oral denticles in proximal corners and a denticulate ooecial plate.

Description. Colony erect, flexible, slender, dichotomously branching. Internodes 4–5 mm long, composed of 10–12 rows of zooids. Joints brownish. Fertile segments slightly thickened. Zooids arranged longitudinally in four alternating series (
A, B). Each new branch starts with a row of three autozooids (
C). Autozooids regularly subhexagonal; longitudinally successive zooids do not touch each other, but are separated by neighbouring zooids of next row, which are offset by 45 ° (
A, B). Distal border rounded, proximal border Vshaped. Borders consist of small ridges with shallow grooves on each side. Fertile zooids in contact with those of offset row and mostly with laterally successive zooid (
B). Cryptocyst mostly smooth, centrally depressed, flanked by two ridges extending from distolateral zooidal borders to proximolateral borders; proximal and distal parts may be very finely granular, but only in some fertile zooids; ridges slightly converging proximally. Opesia transversely D-shaped, wider than long, proximal margin convex; denticle with acute tip in each proximolateral corner, bent 90 °, directed frontally; distal margin beaded (
A, C). Operculum chitinous, yellowish. Ooecial opening situated at distal end of zooid, distal margin formed by succeeding zooid, semicircular, proximal margin formed by broadly semicircular plate with denticulate edge (
B). No avicularia observed. Circular perforations for kenozooidal rhizoids on swollen area immediately proximal to orifice, in groups of 3–5 (
D, E).

There was no significant difference between the superficial length of a zooid and the length of the zooidal chamber ( p = 0.77 ) ( Tables 2 , 3 ). The arrangement of the individual zooids, not touching the zooids of the preceding row, might allow the zooidal chamber to extend a little further. However, this is only sometimes the case; most zooidal chambers have their proximal end just a little below the level of the orifices of the preceding row, leaving a small area without a cavity, i.e. fully calcified, which corresponds to the lateral contact of the preceding row’s zooids (
). The automatic detection and measurement of the opesiae and rhizoidal pores did not show very clear results (
A, B) because of high variability in orifice dimensions, especially those of the proximal row (
A).

Remarks.Cellaria bafouri n. sp. exhibits some similarities with Cellaria harmelini d’Hondt, 1973 , which was recently redescribed by
Berning ( 2013 )
, and its subspecies Cellaria harmelini tenuis d’Hondt, 1974 , as well as with Cellaria cookae López
de la Cuadra & García-Gómez, 1996 . Cellaria bafouri differs distinctly from C . harmelini and C . harmelini tenuis in having the plate covering the ooecial opening distally larger and rounded, concealing more than half of the opening, and in having much stouter oral denticles. (Note that C . harmelini tenuis differs from C . harmelini in the relative length of its internodes and in lacking thickened fertile segments.) Cellaria bafouri has a smooth cryptocyst, whereas that in C . cookae is granular; C. cookae also has denticles only laterally on the ooecial plate. The absence of avicularia in C. bafouri might not be diagnostic, as there is the possibility that they occur only very rarely and thus are missed in the present sampling.

Smittina cervicornis : NHMUK1911.10 . 1.1428 , Adriatic, 34 m ; NHMUK1887.12 . 9.585 , Cape Verde Islands, 183–274 m ; NHMUK1944.1 . 8.281 , Cape Verde Islands, 183–219 m ; SMF9811 , Riou Island, 34 m ; SMF40011 , Adriatic, 15 m .
Etymology. The species name is derived from the Imraguen, a tribe of Mauritanian fishermen inhabiting the area around Banc d’Arguin.
Diagnosis. Erect, bilaminar Smittina with an oval suboral avicularium on the lyrula within the peristome, orientated longitudinally, almost normal to the direction of growth. Spines absent.

Description. Colony erect, bilaminar, multiserial. Dichotomously branching, internodes flattened (
A). The laminae of each branch are symmetrical to each other with respect to autozooidal arrangement. Autozooids arranged in diagonal series consisting of four autozooids (
A). Neighbouring zooids on narrow side of branch are on same level (
B). Zooids more or less rectangular, distal end rounded, surface convex, boundaries distinct. Sutures in primary calcification straight in cross-sections; serrated in area of secondary calcification (
B). Septular pores simple. Frontal shield cryptocystidean, evenly porous. Primary orifice elongate-semicircular, deeply immersed, lyrula about half as wide as orifice, truncate. Condyles rounded, directed proximomedially. Oral spines absent (
C–E). Proximally, but still on lyrula, distinct oval avicularium, nearly normal to direction of growth. Rostrum oval, rounded, proximal border finely serrate, crossbar complete, with bifid ligula (
C–F). Thick cylindrical peristome develops through secondary calcification, projecting from colony surface, almost concealing primary orifice and in later ontogeny incorporating and almost concealing avicularium. Secondary calcification leads eventually to flattened colony surface, owing to immersion of peristomes and avicularia; peristomial rim forms circular or oval secondary orifice that eventually becomes constricted in middle by ‘pseudocondyles’, separating avicularium from orifice and resulting in keyhole shape (
F). Zooids early in astogeny form encrusting base (
G, H); these zooids have lyrula with median ridge, and peristomes sometimes closed by secondary calcification during ontogeny, leading to bulbous appearance (
H). Ancestrula same shape as autozooids, but smaller and with fewer pores (
G). Ovicells not observed.

Micro-CT imaging and quantification. Interior zooidal chamber larger transversely than basal-frontally (
A, B). Avicularium connected mediofrontally to zooidal chamber, immediately proximal to orifice (
C, D); avicularian chamber shaped like rugby ball, orientated transversely and perpendicular to rostrum, and tapering laterally around zooidal chamber. Two or three frontal pores arise from avicularian chamber, indistinguishable from other frontal pores originating from autozooidal chamber (
E). Frontal pores cylindrical (
C, D).

Orificial and frontal-pore measurements form three clusters (
F, 9 ): a large cluster of 441 data points plots between 20 and 50 µm; a second group of 18 data points between 180 and 240 µm, with a mean of 209 µm; and a third group of 56 data points ranging in size from 50 to 140 µm. This last group is most evident in the length plot (
A), while in the width plot separation from the second group is less distinct (
B).

Difficulties in species identification arise from intracolony variation owing to increasing calcification during ontogeny. While peristomes and avicularia are easily discernible in younger parts of the colony, they become scarcely discernible in older parts. The zooidal boundaries also become more irregular and partly occluded. These limitations can be overcome by using micro-CT imaging techniques or by viewing distal branch segments in the early ontogenic stage. As the internal basal and lateral walls were not completely resolved during the scan, owing to comparatively low acceleration voltage resulting in only a fragmentary reconstruction, we cannot describe the distribution and shape of communication pores. It is evident from the reconstructed transverse stack that new zooids originate from the median lamina, simultaneously on each side.

Remarks.Smittina imragueni n. sp. closely resembles S. cervicornis (
Pallas, 1766 )
. Smittina cervicornis is one of the bryozoans mentioned earliest in the literature, as references to this species can be traced back to
Imperato ( 1599 )
, who described and figured an erect, laminar, branching species from the Mediterranean as “ Porus cervinus ”. However, confusion exists concerning the actual type , as Pallas’s collection appears to be lost (
Kuklinski & Taylor 2008 ) and no lectotype has been designated. Pallas also did not provide any figures.

Smittina imragueni n. sp. differs from an Adriatic specimen of S. cervicornis (NHM 1911.10.1.1428) in the position of the avicularium. In the Adriatic colony, it is positioned in the same plane as the frontal surface, whereas in S. imragueni it extends from the lyrula along the proximal peristomial margin, resulting in a more oblique orientation relative to the direction of colony growth. The distal end of the rostrum is also more acute in the Adriatic specimen. It is noteworthy that this Adriatic specimen, which is part of the Canon Alfred Merle Norman collection, has a type label that is amended by “?part of type material”. A small included note states that it was originally described as “ Porella tubulifera Heller
” and was apparently sent by Camil Heller. Another species from the Adriatic ( SMF40011 ) has the avicularium oriented 35 ° to 45 ° from the direction of zooidal growth, which still appears less oblique than in S. imragueni . The avicularium itself also has an acute rostrum. Material from the Adriatic figured by
Hayward & McKinney ( 2002 )
as Smittina cervicornis seems to be this species. A western Mediterranean specimen from Riou Island ( SMF9811 ) has the same more-frontal orientation of the avicularium as the Adriatic specimens, but the shape of the rostrum appears similar to that in S. imragueni , though it is even more acute. At present, it is uncertain whether the Riou Island specimen is conspecific with Adriatic S. cervicornis . Two other specimens at the NHM, from the Cape Verde Islands, also recorded as S. cervicornis , which were originally described as Porella laevis
var. subcompressa Busk, 1884 (NHM 1887.12 . 9.585 and NHM 1944.1.8.281), show the same orientation of the avicularium as the Mediterranean species, but differ from S. imragueni and S. cervicornis in other aspects of zooid morphology and in having differently shaped and also dimorphic suboral avicularia.

Another similar species is the less well-known Smittina colletti (
Jullien & Calvet, 1903 )
, which differs from S. imragueni in the orientation and the relative size of the suboral avicularium and S. colletti also has a characteristic median denticle on top of the lyrula. The zooidal sizes given by
Harmelin ( 1969 )
for S. colletti are significantly smaller than those for S. imragueni .

Strong secondary calcification and intracolony variation complicate identification for these three species, and close attention should be given to the shape and orientation of the suboral avicularium. Further studies might reveal the true identity of Smittina cervicornis s.s.

Difficulties in species identification arise from intracolony variation owing to increasing calcification during ontogeny. While peristomes and avicularia are easily discernible in younger parts of the colony, they become scarcely discernible in older parts. The zooidal boundaries also become more irregular and partly occluded. These limitations can be overcome by using micro-CT imaging techniques or by viewing distal branch segments in the early ontogenic stage. As the internal basal and lateral walls were not completely resolved during the scan, owing to comparatively low acceleration voltage resulting in only a fragmentary reconstruction, we cannot describe the distribution and shape of communication pores. It is evident from the reconstructed transverse stack that new zooids originate from the median lamina, simultaneously on each side.

Remarks.Smittina imragueni n. sp. closely resembles S. cervicornis (
Pallas, 1766 )
. Smittina cervicornis is one of the bryozoans mentioned earliest in the literature, as references to this species can be traced back to
Imperato ( 1599 )
, who described and figured an erect, laminar, branching species from the Mediterranean as “ Porus cervinus ”. However, confusion exists concerning the actual type , as Pallas’s collection appears to be lost (
Kuklinski & Taylor 2008 ) and no lectotype has been designated. Pallas also did not provide any figures.

Smittina imragueni n. sp. differs from an Adriatic specimen of S. cervicornis (NHM 1911.10.1.1428) in the position of the avicularium. In the Adriatic colony, it is positioned in the same plane as the frontal surface, whereas in S. imragueni it extends from the lyrula along the proximal peristomial margin, resulting in a more oblique orientation relative to the direction of colony growth. The distal end of the rostrum is also more acute in the Adriatic specimen. It is noteworthy that this Adriatic specimen, which is part of the Canon Alfred Merle Norman collection, has a type label that is amended by “?part of type material”. A small included note states that it was originally described as “ Porella tubulifera Heller
” and was apparently sent by Camil Heller. Another species from the Adriatic ( SMF40011 ) has the avicularium oriented 35 ° to 45 ° from the direction of zooidal growth, which still appears less oblique than in S. imragueni . The avicularium itself also has an acute rostrum. Material from the Adriatic figured by
Hayward & McKinney ( 2002 )
as Smittina cervicornis seems to be this species. A western Mediterranean specimen from Riou Island ( SMF9811 ) has the same more-frontal orientation of the avicularium as the Adriatic specimens, but the shape of the rostrum appears similar to that in S. imragueni , though it is even more acute. At present, it is uncertain whether the Riou Island specimen is conspecific with Adriatic S. cervicornis . Two other specimens at the NHM, from the Cape Verde Islands, also recorded as S. cervicornis , which were originally described as Porella laevis
var. subcompressa Busk, 1884 (NHM 1887.12 . 9.585 and NHM 1944.1.8.281), show the same orientation of the avicularium as the Mediterranean species, but differ from S. imragueni and S. cervicornis in other aspects of zooid morphology and in having differently shaped and also dimorphic suboral avicularia.

Another similar species is the less well-known Smittina colletti (
Jullien & Calvet, 1903 )
, which differs from S. imragueni in the orientation and the relative size of the suboral avicularium and S. colletti also has a characteristic median denticle on top of the lyrula. The zooidal sizes given by
Harmelin ( 1969 )
for S. colletti are significantly smaller than those for S. imragueni .

Strong secondary calcification and intracolony variation complicate identification for these three species, and close attention should be given to the shape and orientation of the suboral avicularium. Further studies might reveal the true identity of Smittina cervicornis s.s.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Acquisition of morphological data in bryozoans—SEM vs microcomputed tomography analyses. The current methodological standard in describing bryozoan species with a calcified skeleton is the employment of SEM. This method results in high-resolution images of even the tiniest structures, and modern devices do not require a conductive specimen surface, i.e. coating of specimens. Because the SEM is based upon the emission of nearsurface electrons, visualising internal skeletal structures requires complete or partial destruction. To address this problem, serial thin sections have been commonly utilized, fragmenting a specimen into single slices, which has proven to be especially useful for Paleozoic
Bryozoa (
Wyse Jackson & McKinney 2013 )
. However, resolution is limited by the thickness of the sections. For the complete spatial visualisation of internal cavities, resin casts have proven to be very useful, but require dissolution of the entire specimen (e.g.
Wiesemann 1960 ;
Voigt 1968 ;
Voigt & Williams 1973 ). Partial or complete loss of specimens has likely hampered using the structure and shape of internal cavities for the taxonomic description of species, although
Voigt & Williams ( 1973 )
highlighted the value of these characters.

Micro-CT techniques allow the non-destructive visualisation of internal structures not only in 2 -dimensional slices but also in 3 -dimensional virtual models, under the premise that the material contrast is reasonably high, which is usually met in Recent, non-fossilised specimens. Using virtual models, it is further possible to show or hide different parts, thus enabling visualisation of the deepest internal structures and their relation to each other.

Some researchers have already used micro-CT to investigate the internal structures of bryozoans. While Koromyslova & Pakhnevich ( 2014 ), Koromyslova et al . ( 2014 ) and
Wyse Jackson & McKinney ( 2013 )
used virtual slices similar to traditional thin-sectioning, without making a 3 -dimensional reconstruction,
Schmidt ( 2012 )
used micro-CT to investigate qualitatively the internal structure by 3 -dimensional visualisation.
Viskova & Pakhnevich ( 2010 )
and
Wyse Jackson & McKinney ( 2013 )
additionally made some measurements on virtual sections, and
Klicpera et al . ( 2013 )
employed this technique to assess the weight and volume of a bryozoan skeleton, hence obtaining quantified data from the virtual dataset. Our study took the analysis of quantified micro- CT data a step further by automatically measuring the volume and extent not only of all zooidal chambers, but also of smaller individual structures like suboral avicularia, rhizoidal kenozooids, and even frontal pores.

Another aspect to consider is the exact location of measurements. This is exemplified by orifice length in S. imragueni n. sp. , which was significantly smaller in the micro-CT data than in measurements made on SEM micrographs. This was because the micro-CT measurements of the diameter of the orifice were conducted at a shallower position in the skeleton, approximately between the secondary orifice and the most basal part of the lyrula, while the proximal boundary of the true primary orifice is hidden by the lyrula. The micro-CT measurements of the orifices had to be positioned in this way in order to automatically detect all distances at once. Also, the micro-CT measurements of external zooid width were significantly larger than the SEM measurements. This difference was likely caused by some laterally growing tubules of frontal pores, which were included in the automatically measured autozooid width in the CT analysis (
C, D), as they were regarded by the algorithm as belonging to the main autozooidal chamber. Care thus has to be taken in comparing optical/SEM measurements with those taken by micro-CT.

The micro-CT measurements suggest that for S. imragueni n. sp. the size of the avicularian chamber is positively correlated with the size of the zooidal chamber ( Tables 6 , 7 ), and for C. bafouri n. sp. that the opesiae on the inner side of the bend are slightly smaller than those on the outside (
B). No correlation was observed between autozooidal and avicularian volumes, which might have resulted from the small sample size ( 8 pairs); apart from this, measurements of different astogenic stages of a colony would be necessary to give a biologically robust answer on how strongly zooid size influences avicularium size. The same holds true for size variation of the opesia in relation to the presence of rhizoids or their position in the bent colony.

When micro-CT becomes more accessible and easier to use, it will be possible to implement such internal morphological characters and their dimensions, which were previously difficult to observe, into species descriptions on a regular basis, and to amend species descriptions based on conventional methods.

Faulwetter et al . ( 2013 )
discussed the application of micro-CT as a component of the growing field of cybertaxonomy, which is based on virtual taxonomic material, using polychaetes as an example. The most crucial requirements for establishing volumetric datasets, and for providing more than just additional data in taxonomic research, are the standardisation of file types and the introduction of adequate repositories and handling policies (
Rowe & Frank 2011 ). The International Code of Zoological Nomenclature might eventually have to implement rules regarding the handling and systematic value of such virtual type-relevant material, possibly leading to the introduction of the so-called ‘cybertype’, which is considered by some authors as a new kind of type specimen (
Faulwetter et al . 2013 ;
Godfray 2007 ). These types are simultaneously accessible to multiple researchers in different places, without the necessity of handling the original physical specimen, leading to increased speed in taxonomic research. However, such virtual type material cannot replace physical specimens, as only the original specimen carries all information and any virtualisation is a mere copy with reduced information content. It is also not desirable to base species descriptions solely on characters requiring complex and time-consuming equipment or destruction of specimens. ‘Cybertypes’ should be considered only as a standardised way to represent type specimens and distribute taxonomic data, but not as replacements for physical specimens.

Except for station GeoB 14888 - 1 , live S. imragueni was absent at the stations with the lowest oxygen concentrations, and at GeoB 14888 - 1 only a few colonies were observed, indicating a higher oxygen sensitivity than for C. bafouri . This is certainly the consequence of larger zooid size of S. imragueni , but primarily to the closed frontal area, with only some pores allowing gas exchange, compared to the large frontal membrane of C. bafouri . Additionally, the secretion of calcium carbonate is impeded in low-oxygen environments (
Rhoads & Morse 1971 ), and a possible adaptation might be a more weakly calcified skeleton. Smittina imragueni , however, shows strong secondary calcification, indicating that this species is capable of maintaining its level of calcification under low oxygen conditions. However, the absence of S. imragueni from habitats with an extremely low oxygen concentration might indicate a higher oxygen demand of this species compared to C. bafouri . In conclusion, it appears that both species can tolerate low oxygen conditions to a certain degree if the nutrient supply is reasonably high.
